channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: A job with real flexibility. 100% remote Perl position
item.description: As one of the most popular open-source ticketing systems on the planet, this team knows what it takes to attract organizations of all sizes. Our client is looking for a Perl developer who has Mason, Moose, Mojolicious and experience with ticketing systems.

item.title: Summer is calling! Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international financial company with offices around the world. With a global presence and the kind of growth that would make a beanstalk blush, they’re looking to expand their team. If you’re a Perl programmer with a side interest in online trading, you’ll be a natural in this role.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: Perl programmers, lean in — this is the opportunity for you if your happy place is at home in your fuzzy bunny slippers. The role is 100% remote friendly for those located in the UK, so kick back and enjoy your commute-free existence. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within UK, South Africa and Switzerland
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. The ideal candidate will have automated payment experience in addition to their strong Perl background.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: Our client is currently looking to staff up some Jr. Perl developers for a 100% remote (within the UK), permanent position. They want to find some fresh talent that can adapt and flourish in this role. Having modern Perl foundations and understandings is important, but the client is willing to overlook some knowledge gaps for the right developer who is eager to learn.

item.title: Jews Don't Count
item.description: A very interesting analyzis on how the people who care about the rights of every minority seem to overlook one particular minority.

item.title: Monthly Report - October
item.description: I am glad to see Mohammad still sticks to his monthly reports!

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;

item.title: berrybrew version 1.36 released!
item.description: Berrybrew, the Perlbrew for Windows.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 137
item.description: Simon brought an interesting topic in the discussion. This is one of the benefit you have with the blog. So easy to sharing the knowledge. Thanks as always.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 137: Long Cheryl
item.description: Roger made the Long Year task looks so simple. It is magical. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 137
item.description: I really Luis one-liner. It so much fun decode the code. Even Lychrel number turned into one-liner. Great. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 137: palindrome sums on long year
item.description: Luca recent started sharing solution in PostgreSQL along with Raku. What a bonus we got, thanks Luca.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 137: Long Year and Lychrel Number
item.description: A very unique approach to Long Year task. Great discussion. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #137
item.description: James once again gone beyond the task and shared his analysis of Lychrel Number task. It is always pleasure reading his blog. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC137 - Lychrel Number
item.description: Discussion made code reading so easy, anyone can follow the code. Thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.

item.title: PWC137 - Long Year
item.description: I enjoy Raku solution more than the Perl. It is so obvious written by Perl developer. Great piece of work as always.

item.title: Lychrel Longing with Raku and Perl
item.description: I am not sure if you noticed, Arne always does varieties of solution of the same task. Plenty to keep you entertained. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 137: Lychrel Number
item.description: I appreciate the amount of werk put in to prepare the brilliant blog. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 137: Long Year
item.description: Abigail's blog is more than just about the task. Plenty of ideas to explore. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 134
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 137
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Long Year" and "Lychrel Number" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 138
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Workdays" and "Split Number". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Perl Tk: The label, button, and entry widgets
Yancy: What We Leave Behind
item.description: Yancy is a Content Management System, and now 4 years after its initial release, Yancy is on its way to becoming the M in Mojolicious MVC.

item.title: Proxy setup for Netcat in Perl
Some thoughts on Perl template processing
item.description: Template processors and engines are one of those pieces of software where it seems every developer wants to reinvent the wheel. Goodness knows I’ve done it earlier in my career. Tell me if this sounds familiar?

item.title: #537 - How do you spend your free time?
item.description:
Hi

The Perl Weekly newsletter is more than 10 years old and during those years we have witnessed a huge decline in the number and diversity of posts. There are still a few people who write about Perl regularly, The Weekly Challenge of Mohammad generates many posts, but in general we see fewer and fewer posts.

I wonder, do those people who used to write about Perl write about other technologies or have they just stopped? How come that so few people write about Perl? Are there no new things in Perl? Are there no new problems that one solves in Perl?

I know that writing about stuff is not the same thing as writing the stuff, but as many other people who write or teach will attest, the best way to improve your knowledge is to explain it. to explain it to live audience (at a Meetup) or to write about it in a blog post.

So how do you spend your free time? Do you write more code? Do you try to explain what you wrote, how you wrote and why? Or do you spend your time on some other activities? I, for examples started to read a lot more than I did in the recent years. And sure, I'll even share my recommendations with you. (See bellow.)

In any case enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
